document.text: Wrack Island Extension Homemakers Club Matting Mrs. Marie Carson was hostess to the Wreck Island Ex tension Homemakers Club when it met in her home o n  Wednesday, September 20, at H30 p.m. There were 12 mem bers in attenance. One new member, Mrs. Zolene Harding was added to the roll. Mrs. Elsie Thornhill led devotions and prayer. She chose for the scripture reading Matt.7l-5. She gave a reading. The topic was Fog Dims The View . Hie secretary read the minutes and it was approved and the treasurer report was given. Mrs. Dixie Staten led the group in the Homemakers Creed. A business session wàs con ducted by our president, Mrs. Dixie Staten of announcements with dates of interest to mem bers. September 23-24 - Railroad Festival - The Appomattox County Homemakers are preparing a float for the Railroad Festival . The Float Committee decided that one person from each homemakers gçoup will be on the float to sing. Mrs. Frances Dyess will represent our club. September 28 Leader Training for October. Dr. Eldridge R. Collins, Exten sion Specialist with Ag Engineering will do the Leader Training Session for October. Sessions will be held at 130 p.m. and 730 p.m. on Safe Wood Burning in Stoves and Fireplaces. September 30, 1978 Achievement Day - to be held at the Appomattox County High School cafeteria for the Ap pomattox County Homemakers at 6 p.m. The theme for this program is Todays 4-Hers Tomorrows Homemakers. Three of our members, Mrs. Rose Burnett, Mrs. Mane Car- son and Mrs. Dixie Staten have signed up for needlepoint workshops that Dr. Helen Whidden of Lynchburg is con ducting September 7, 8, 14, 15, 19 and 21. It was announced that Mrs. Tilden Lee entered exhibits on canned goods, horticulture and flowers at the Five County Fair in Farmville, Sept. 11-16. She won 24 ribbons on her en tries. Thirteen blue ribbons were won which was the greatest number of blue ribbons won in the adult division to win the Grand Champion Award Trophy plus 10.00. Mrs. Lee entered seven exhibits at State Fair,- Rich mond, Va., and won seven rib bons, 4 of which were blue rib bons for her entries. Mrs. Ruth Carson, Federation Goal Chairman, gave a program topic, A Goal For Everyone. Breads of the World was the topic of the demonstration given by Mrs. Rose Burnett. A social hour followed when the hostess served delicious refreshments to the group. The October meeting will be held in the home of Mrs. Mary Taylor on Wed., Oct. 18, at 130 p.m. A demonstration on Safety to be given. The topic Safe Woodburning - Stoves and Fireplaces. Mrs. Tilden Lee, Secretary

document.text: Would you like the Home coming Football  game baU for a keepsake or to have it to do with whatever you so desire? It could be yours! Through the co-operation of head coach, Jerry Robinson, and his staff, the  game ball has been donated to the Appo mattox County Rescue Squad to be used in an effort to raise funds for their Canteen Fund which is completely down to a zero balance. F r i d a y , November 5th, is H o m e c o m i n g at Appomattox County High School. Festivities begin with a parade in the after noon, followed by the kick-off of its Homecoming Football game at Bragg Stadium at 8 p. m. when the mighty Raiders take on a strong team from Altavis ta High School and ending with a Homecoming Dance in the Gym from 10 to 12 p.m. spon sored by the senior class. By 700 p.m., members of the Appomattox County R e s c u e Squad wiU be stationed inside the gate and throughout the stadium offering chances on the  game ball for a donation of 25Ç each or 5 chances for one dollar. All three of the Rescue Squad vehicles will be partici pating in the parade and will be on stand-by throughout the game and tickets can be obtained at any of the three vehicles. In cidents, if you have not seen the new SWAB Ambulance, you are invited to do so Friday night. Money for the ACRS Canteen Fund has, in the past, been earn ed by the members of the Squad by having bake sales, selling food at Auction Sales and vari ous other money making pro jects. Money from this Fund is used for kitchen supplies coffee and such, for flowers or gifts sent to hospitalized crew mem bers, for a dinner once a year for the members at the Installa tion of Officers meeting and for several needed items not bought with money from the General Fund. Your support in this pro ject will be appreciated. Thanks to Coach Robinson and all those at Appomattox County High School who have made this possible. Bring with you some extra change . . . who knows, you may be the lucky one who takes home the prized  game ball . Drawing will take place just after the half-time activi ties.

document.text: With two golfers returning from last years team. Coach Coty Dickerson is looking for help from six new players in the 1981 version of the Appomattox County High School golf team. Junior Richard Guill and Mike Smith, a sophomore, are both coming back from last, years Raider golf team. Newcomers include freshman Bobby C arter, sophomores Mike Williams and Jay Stew art, junior Mike Richardson, and seniors Dana White end Joe Brooks. According to Dickerson, Guill will likely be the number-one player on this years team. Dickersoq points out that Guill qualified for the regional tournament last year, and missed qualifying for the state tournament by only one stroke.  The Raiders will play nine dual matches this year, according to Dickerson, with the first scheduled for tomor row against Altavista at the Falling River Country Club course. We feel like, we have a lot of potential in thé young players, Dickerson says. Theyve been ehthuaigstic. and have worked very hard thus far in practice. Dickerson will have to fill the positions vacated by his number two, three and four players on last years team. John Simmons is playing baseball this year, and Steve Mayberry and Tun Tolley are both working this year. . Dickerson says that Gary Howard, the pro at Falling River Country Club, where the Raiders practice, has been very helpful and donated his time to help instruct the players. The district powerhouse? this year will likely indur Altavista, who won the distri tournament last year, ar.u Liberty, who has many players from the 1980 team returning to play this year. Qualifying rounds for the first match of the season were scheduled to be held yesterday Tuesday and today, according to Dickerson.

document.text: With ten lovely young ladies competing Saturday evening in bathing suit, talent, and evening dress competition for the title of MISS APPOMATTOX - 1976, Miss Pamela Louise Chenault was selected for the title by a team of judges and crowned MISS APPOMATTOX by Miss Lynn White, the former MISS APPOMATTOX. Napcy Carol Chambers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Wayne Jones, a sophomore at Longwood College was 1st Runner-Up and Sandy Chambers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Chambers, a senior at Appomattox County High School, was named 2nd Runner Up. Pam, the new MISS APPOMATTOX, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Chenault of Appomattox, is a junior at Lynchburg General Marshall Lodge Hospital School of Nursing and plans to work toward her B.S. degree. She was 1st Runner-Up in the 1975 pageant. She will represent Appomattox County in various events during the coming year and will participate as a contestant in thr Miss Virginia pageant in Roanoke. -  The MISS APPOMATTOX pageant is sponsored annually by the Appomattox Womans Club. The Appomattox Beauty Shop was the sponsor of Miss Chenault in the pageant.

document.text: When the 1975 RAILROAD ESTIVAL PARADE gets underway at 10 a.m. Saturday, October 11, an endeavor of the . Appomattox Junior Womans Club and the Town of Appomattox, music, beauty, listory and elected leaders local, state, and national will e featured. United States Senator Harry Flood Byrd, Jr. will be the Parade Grand Marshall leading the parade behind the music of the Appomattox County High School Band. Senator Byrd, a native of Winchester, received his edu cation at Virginia Military Institute and at the University of Virginia. A veteran of World War Q, he was elected to the Senate of Virginia six times serving from 1948 to 1965. Byrd was appointed to the United States Senate in November of 1966, was elected in 1966 as a Democrat lor a four year term and was reelected in 1970 as an Independent for another six year term ending in 1977. He is the second person in history to be elected to the U.8. Senate as an Independent candidate. A member of the Democratic State Central Committee from 1940 to 1966, Chairman of the , Virginia Advisory Board on Industrial Development from 1962 to 1967, he is publisher of a number of daily newspapers in the vklley including the Winchester Star. He is the son of the late Harry Flood Byrd, a former U.S. Senator and the grandson at Mrs. Bolling Flood Byrd who was born and raised in Appomattox. Immediately following the parade. Senator Byrd will participate in ceremonies held on the platform at the Depot and will be the guest speaker. Seventy-two entries are slated to march in Saturdays parade as Artie Levin, well known television celebrity, participates as Master of Ceremonies for the 1,975 parade. The parade will depart from Virginia Department of High ways parking lot at 10 a.m. and will follow a route along Morton Lane, Court Street, down Main Street, will go up Church Street, along Highland Avenue back to Court Street, then along Ferguson Street to the Appomattox Primary School where they will disband. This 1975 parade should bo the grandest ever in Appomat tox and most certainly will be the largest.

As recipient of the Blue Ridge Chapter DAR Award, Vivian is now eligible to compete in the District Good Citizens Contest. document.text: Whats a pipe chaser? These three students, all juniors at Appomattox County High School, know the answer to that one because they are also brick layers. Their mortar is a special mixture so that todays construction can be knocked down for another tvoe of construction another time. They work with plumb lines, trowels, brick and block under the eye of George B. Almond, instructor at the masony shop at Appomattox Intermediate School. When they leave school theyll be eligible for immediate employment, says Mr. Almond and the demand for construction workers continues to grow. So,  whats a pipe chaser? Thats the type of brick wall construction as above which allows room for a pipe to be placed adjacent to the all, possibly through it. Example, a water line to be brought into a home. The brick layers are Kenneth Mosley, Clarence Napier and Marvin Austin.

document.text: Wanda Forest, a ninth grader at Appomattox County High School, was crowned Miss FHA for the Campbell-Appo- mattox Federation, Future Homemakers of America at Skateland in Lynchburg on Nov. 15,1976. An active member of the FHA chapter, Wanda serves as President of her Home Econo mics class chapter. She is historian for the Tri-Hi-Y Club and a member of Promise Land Baptist Church. Wanda is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd S. Forest, Sr. of Spout Spring. The penny-a-vote contest is sponsored by the Federation as its only money-making project. FHAHERO members from Appomattox and Campbell counties participated in the trip to Skateland. Wanda wishes to thank all those who contributed for her.

document.text: W hatever your taste in musical entertainment. . . from jazz-rock and lively show tunes to the traditional favorites . . . Virignia TechsNEW VIRGIN IANS are just what youve been waiting to hear. The 32-voice choral group aqd its 10-member stage band, about as untraditional a college choral group as youll find anywhere, will appear in concert here April 5, sponsored by the Appomattox Lions Club. And when the song-happy youngsters led by director Stan Kingma scramble onto the stage at the Appomattox County High School, youll know from the moment you see them that something is happen ing that few college groups ever even dream about. The NEW VIRGINIANS are the 1974-75 version of what for the past two years has stormed Virginia with its new concert format. Not many people will fail to notice the colorful showtime costumes and well-scrubbed look of the collegiate singers. It all helps set the mood for the extraordinary music. Just what kind of music the NEW VIRGINIANS will focus upon at the concert will depend largely on what the audience wants to hear. Each of the groups shows is keyed precise ly to the audience at hand. Its like coversation, in a way, Kingma says, we speak to the audience with music, and decide by its reaction what song or sequence well sing next.

document.text: Victory in Jesus, a county wide crusade, will be held April 26 through May 1 in the Appomattox County High School auditorium, at 730 each night. Guest evangelist for . the  crusade will be Vander Warner, pastor of the Grove Avenue Baptist Church in Richmond, whose Sunday morning wor ship services are featured each week on Richmond television. Warner s currently serving on the committee on boards for the Southern Baptist Conven tion in 1981. He preached in city-wide Crusades in two cities in Nigeria in 1973 for the foreign mission board, with more than 1,500 professions of faith recorded. He also has a crusade scheduled for India in 1981. In the past two years, the . Grove Avenue Baptist Church  has. experienced a 40 percent increase in membership. William Souther will lead the music for the crusade. He is minister of ipusic for Grove Baptist Church. document.text: Trophies Presented To ACHS Athletes r X ACHS Athletes who received awards for outstanding performances during the Winter sports season. Trophies were t presented at the annual Winter Sports banquet sponsored t jointly by the Appomattox County High School and the Lion s -Club. Connie Murray, front left, received award for Most Valuable Player in Volleyball. Vickie Thomas, front right, was presented the Sportsmanship Award. Football awards included back row. left to right, Mitch Eggleston, Most Valuable Defensive Back and Kicker, Bennett Paulette, Unsung Hero award, Phil Jamerson, Most Valuable Lineman, William BooBoo Trent, Moat Valuable Player and Most Valuable Offensive Back, anfay Franklin, Most Improved Player.
